questions.question:
Question 1: An upper GI endoscopy is performed in a patient with dyspeptic symptoms. It shows the 
presence of thickened gastric folds. Which of the following differential diagnoses would you 
not consider in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pancreatic rests are not a differential diagnosis for hypertrophied gastric folds. These usually 
present as a single lump in the stomach and are formed by ectopic pancreatic tissue. 441 
Sold by @itachibot Thickened gastric folds can represent a local malignant process, inflammatory process, or 
hormonal response. The differential diagnoses of large gastric folds include: • Menetrier's disease • Zollinger–Ellison syndrome - hypergastrinemia leads to parietal cell hyperplasia and prominent 
folds • Malignancy- lymphoma, infiltrating gastric cancer • Infections- histoplasmosis, tuberculosis.

questions.question: Question 2: Which part of the stomach is usually spared in Menetrier's disease?
questions.explanation:
The antrum is usually spared in Menetrier's disease. Foveolar hyperplasia results in the development of large rugal folds in the body and fundus of the 
stomach, sparing the antrum. These hypertrophied rugal folds give a cobblestone or cerebriform 
appearance to the gastric mucosa. The image given below shows the endoscopic appearance of Menetrier's disease.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 46-year-old man presented with a history of diarrhea for 5 months, occasional abdominal 
pain, and weight loss. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following finding. Which of the 
following is least likely to occur in this patient? 437 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario and endoscopy image showing large, rugal gastric folds are suggestive of 
Menetrier's disease. Among the given options, hematemesis is least likely to occur in this patient. Large, gastric rugal folds in Menetrier's disease occur due to massive overgrowth of mucous 
cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach. Patients usually present with epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral 
edema, and weight loss. Occult gastrointestinal bleeding may occur, but overt bleeding is 
unusual. If overt bleeding is seen, it is usually due to superficial mucosal erosions. 442 
Sold by @itachibot They develop protein-losing gastropathy, leading to hypoproteinemia as a result of increased 
secretion of gastric mucus. There is also a decrease in the number of parietal cells which leads to 
decreased acid secretion (hypochlorhydria) in the stomach. They are at an increased risk of 
developing gastric carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 6-year-old child with vomiting, abdominal pain, weight loss, and peripheral edema 
underwent an upper GI biopsy. Histology showed foveolar hyperplasia and glandular atrophy 
within the gastric mucosa. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Menetrier's disease. In children, it occurs commonly due 
to the infection by cytomegalovirus. The histopathological features of Menetrier's disease include: • Foveolar hyperplasia - hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosa • Reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells • Dilated, tortuous gastric glands • Elongation of pits of gastric glands • Eosinophilic infiltration in lamina propria The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.

questions.question: Question 5: Overexpression of which of the following causes Menetrier’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Overexpression of TGF- (transforming growth factor-alpha) causes Menetrier's disease. This 
overexpression results in overstimulation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) 
pathway and increased proliferation of mucous cells, resulting in mucous cell (foveolar) 
hyperplasia. 443 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 24-year old woman underwent extensive workup for unexplained weight loss, vomiting, and 
diarrhea. She was suspected to have Menetrier's disease. Which of the following 
investigations will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Menetrier's disease is confirmed by endoscopic full-thickness biopsy. A full-thickness biopsy allows for the visualization of the cells on the surface as well as the pits of 
the gastric glands. The histopathological specimen shows the following features: • Foveolar hyperplasia - hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosa • Reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells • Dilated, tortuous gastric glands • Elongation of pits of gastric glands • Eosinophilic infiltration in lamina propria A punch biopsy can only sample the surface of the gastric gland and hence is not preferred. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.

questions.question:
Question 7: A middle-aged man presented with a history of dyspepsia. He has been taking pantoprazole 
for the last few months, however, his symptoms persisted. Upper GI endoscopy was done, 
and a full-thickness gastric biopsy was taken. The histopathological appearance is shown 
below. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing foveolar hyperplasia are suggestive of 
Menetrier's disease. The treatment of choice is cetuximab. Increased epidermal growth factor receptor(EGFR) signaling has been implicated in the 
pathogenesis of Menetrier's disease. Cetuximab is an EGFR inhibitor, and blocks this signaling 
pathway and helps in the improvement of the symptoms. Therefore, it is the first line of 
treatment. Medical therapy with proton pump inhibitors (lansoprazole) and somatostatin analogues 
(octreotide) may also be tried to manage symptoms. If the patient continues to have protein loss 
despite medical therapy, then total gastrectomy is indicated. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease. 444 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common site for a MALToma?
questions.explanation:
The most common site for mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma or MALToma is 
the stomach. MALToma is a type of extranodal marginal zone lymphoma that most commonly occurs in the 
stomach and to a lesser extent in the salivary glands, lungs, small intestine, etc. It occurs as a 
result of the malignant proliferation of B cells in the marginal zone of mucosa-associated 
lymphoid tissue (MALT).

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is false about MALTomas?

options.b: History of chronic gastritis usually seen

questions.explanation:
MALToma arises from B lymphocytes present in the marginal zone of the lymphoid tissue. The majority of the cases of MALToma are associated with H. pylori induced chronic gastritis. 
This infection results in an increased proliferation of lymphocytes in the mucosa of the stomach 
causing MALToma. It is initially low grade and if the infection is not treated, it later progresses to 
high grade. The patients usually present with non-specific symptoms like epigastric pain and discomfort. It is 
usually diagnosed in patients around 60 years of age. It is also associated with autoimmune 
diseases like Sjogren's syndrome and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 62-year-old woman underwent an endoscopic biopsy of a gastric tumor. The biopsy shows 
dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands. Which of 
the following investigations will confirm your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and lymphoepithelial lesions seen in the gastric glands is suggestive of 
MALToma. The diagnosis is confirmed by immunophenotyping. 445 
Sold by @itachibot Histopathological examination of a MALToma shows the presence of lymphoepithelial 
lesions. These are caused due to the invasion of gastric glands and crypts by the neoplastic 
lymphocytes. These lymphocytes are positive for CD19, CD20 and negative for CD5 and CD10. 
Biopsy or aspiration of the bone marrow is also done to see the bone marrow involvement. Radiological investigations like CT scans, MRIs, and PET scans are useful in identifying the extent 
of the tumor and infiltration of the tumor to the adjacent organs. Note: Cytogenetic testing will be helpful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of a MALToma. The below image shows a sample of a MALToma showing positive immunophenotyping for CD20. 446 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Immunophenotyping from a gastric tumor in an elderly man showed the following findings. 
The tumor was found to be limited to the gastric mucosa. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a low-grade gastric MALToma. The treatment of choice for 
this condition is H. pylori eradication therapy which can be done with the OCM 
regimen (omeprazole, clarithromycin and metronidazole). Immunophenotyping in MALTomas shows positive staining for CD19 and CD20 which is 
suggestive of a B-cell neoplasm. Negative staining for CD5 and CD10 is seen, suggesting it arises 
from the marginal zone of lymphoid tissues. Chronic infection with H. pylori leads to the development of MALTomas. When these lesions are 
limited to the mucosa, treatment of the infection alone is sufficient to cause regression of the 
tumour. In high-grade tumors or the tumors which invade into the adjacent or distant organs, 
radiotherapy and chemotherapy are required to treat the tumor. Radiotherapy is usually 
three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used in the treatment of 
MALToma are rituximab, cyclophosphamide, fludarabine, doxorubicin, vincristine, and 
prednisone. Radical gastrectomy has a limited role and is done when the disease is confined to the 
stomach.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 65-year-old smoker presents with postprandial abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past 1 
year. On examination, she is malnourished, and a bruit is heard in the epigastrium. What is 
the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia. Chronic mesenteric ischemia occurs due to atherosclerosis of the celiac or mesenteric arteries. It 
is common in older women, and they usually have a history of smoking, coronary artery disease, 
cerebrovascular disease, or peripheral artery disease. The important clinical features of chronic mesenteric ischemia are: 447 
Sold by @itachibot • Postprandial abdominal pain occurs as a result of a mismatch between the increased demand 
and decreased blood flow to the intestine. This is called intestinal angina • Weight loss- patients avoid eating due to postprandial pain and this leads to significant weight 
loss • Diarrhea- occurs as a result of decreased absorption • Physical examination may reveal epigastric bruit in almost half of the patients. The gold standard investigation to diagnose the blockade is mesenteric angiography. Once the 
disease is confirmed, the patients have to be started with antiplatelets and mesenteric angioplasty 
and stenting should be performed. Option A: Acute mesenteric ischemia present with acute abdomen, bloody diarrhea and nausea. 
Angiography will show occlusion of superior mesenteric artery. Option C: Wilkie's syndrome occurs due to compression of the third portion of the duodenum by 
the superior mesenteric artery. It can present similarly, however is associated with vomiting and 
rapid weight loss. It usually occurs in young, asthenic women. Option D: Nutcracker syndrome occurs due to compression of the left renal vein, between the 
aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. It presents with varicoceles and hematuria. 448 
Sold by @itachibot Large and medium vessel vasculitis
